frameDefinitions: An Item is detached from a Source, or Items are detached from each other.
A Producer produces a Product from a Resource for commercial purposes. '
This frame describes the Impression which a Figure, which can be a person, an organization, or an object, leaves with an Audience.
The Noise_maker is an artifact used to produce sound, especially for musical effect.
This frame contains nouns that refer to sensations in different modalities.
A phenomenon, the Indicator, exists as an indication of another phenomenon, the Indicated.
frameExamples: When the snow plow is <t>disconnected</t> from the vehicle, extend the lift cylinder to the end of its stroke and coat the chrome rod with a light grease.
They <t>produced</t> only half of the units after an injunction to follow the environmental policy.
He had an extremely fragile self - <t><fex name='Impression'>image</fex></t>
The huge sand dunes, perpetually changing, make for a surreal <t>sight</t>.
This is a <t>sign</t> of things to come.
listRoleDefinitions: <fen>Item</fen> identifies the entity that is detached from a <fen>Source</fen>.
<fen>Items</fen> identifies the plural items that are detached from each other.
<fen>Source</fen> identifies the location from which the <fen>Item</fen>(s) is detached.
The person or company that produces the Product.
The <fen>Product</fen> is produced by the <fen>Producer</fen>.
<fen>Factory</fen> identifies the particular plant where the <fen>Product</fen> is manufactured.
This Fe identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the product was produced.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Product</fen> is manufactured.
The entity (a person, organization, product, or event) for which the <fen>Audience</fen> has an <fen>Impression</fen>.
A person or group of people who have an <fen>Impression</fen> of a <fen>Figure</fen>.
A generalized conception of a <fen>Figure</fen> presented to or shared by an <fen>Audience</fen>.
This role identifies the entity or substance that is designed to produce sound.
This role is only expressed with certain nouns in this frame, and then only with the help of a support verb, such as <ment>have</ment>:

This is the entity or phenomenon which gives rise to the sensation. In cases of veridical sensation, this role is not typically distinguished from <fen>Percept</fen>. Most of the phrases that express this role can be paraphrased as <ment>from</ment>-phrases, e.g.

The role <fen>Percept</fen> is used for phrases that express the characteristic property of a sensation. Typically this characteristic property is described with reference to the entity or phenomenon that produces the sensation---that  is why this role can be difficult to distinguish from Source. It is possible for Source and Percept to be expressed separately, however:

This role is assigned to phrases expressing the body part in which a sensation is located. Since touch is the least localized of sense modalities, words relating to haptic sensations are the ones most likely to occur with this FE:
This role is the perceptual background against which the Phenomenon is experienced by the Perceiver.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the sensation is perceived.
The phenomenon that signifies the <fen>Indicated</fen>.
The phenomenon that is signified by the <fen>Indicator</fen>.
listRoleExamples: I feel like <fex>my head</fex> is detached from the rest of my body.
<fex>The neck vertebrae</fex> are unfused in rorquals and gray whales, which allows for some flexibility at the head and neck.
The toilet is loose <fex>from the floor</fex> and must be repaired.
Those machines were manufactured <fex>in the Miami plant</fex>.
Those leather shoes were made <fex>in Italy</fex>.
<fex>I</fex> have a tingling sensation in my hands.
The smell <fex>of the garlic</fex> made me hungry.
This herb gives off a smell <fex>of garlic</fex>.
I have a tingling feeling <fex>in my hands</fex>.
He was unable to display any <fex>sign</fex> of pain.
We now exhibt the same symptoms <fex>of the same disease</fex>.
